file_metadata.title: Niclosamide rescues microcephaly in a humanized in vivo model of Zika infection using human induced neural stem cells

chunks.text: Zika virus (ZIKV) causes microcephaly, and there is a lack of in vivo models using human neurons and effective treatments. We studied ZIKV's effects on human induced neural stem cells (hiNSCs) in vitro and in vivo using a chick embryo model. In vitro, ZIKV-infected hiNSCs secreted inflammatory cytokines, showed altered differentiation, and underwent apoptosis. Niclosamide (NIC) treatment reduced ZIKV production, partially restored differentiation, and prevented apoptosis in hiNSCs. In vivo, intracranial injection of ZIKV-infected hiNSCs into chick embryos caused microcephaly. Systemic ZIKV infection via the chorioallantoic membrane (CAM) in embryos with hiNSCs also caused microcephaly, which NIC partially rescued. This humanized model allows studying systemic ZIKV infection on human neurons and drug testing.
chunks.chunk_summary: A humanized chick embryo model was used to study ZIKV infection in hiNSCs and the therapeutic potential of niclosamide.
chunks.authors: ["Dana M. Cairns", "Devi Sri Sai Kavya Boorugu", "Michael Levin", "David K. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: Zika virus (ZIKV) is linked to microcephaly. In vitro models using human cells have advanced understanding of ZIKV pathogenesis, but they don't fully replicate the microcephalic phenotype. In vivo mouse models have limitations, including the need for immunocompromised strains and not fully replicating human microcephaly.  No model has combined human neural cells with an in vivo organism to study systemic virus effects and drug treatment on human neurons. We used human induced neural stem cells (hiNSCs) for in vitro and in vivo ZIKV infection models. hiNSCs differentiate into neurons and integrate into chick embryo nervous systems. In vitro, ZIKV-infected hiNSCs secrete ZIKV, inflammatory cytokines, and growth factors; show altered differentiation; and undergo apoptosis. Niclosamide (NIC) reduces ZIKV production, partially restores differentiation, and prevents apoptosis in hiNSCs.
chunks.chunk_summary: Existing ZIKV models have limitations, prompting the development of a humanized in vivo model using hiNSCs and chick embryos.
chunks.authors: ["Dana M. Cairns", "Devi Sri Sai Kavya Boorugu", "Michael Levin", "David K. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: The chick embryo was chosen for the in vivo model because it allows intracranial injection of human neural stem cells, has rapid brain development, and has a naturally immunodeficient system suitable for xenografts and viral infection. Intracranial injection of hiNSCs followed by systemic ZIKV infection via the chorioallantoic membrane (CAM) caused microcephaly in chick embryos, including reduced cranial size, decreased forebrain volume, and enlarged ventricles.  NIC treatment partially rescued ZIKV-induced microcephaly and attenuated hiNSC infection in vivo. This humanized model is unique in studying systemic virus effects on human neurons. The CAM delivery method is physiologically relevant, mimicking transplacental delivery.  High-dose NIC treatment without ZIKV infection had no adverse effects on embryonic development, suggesting it may not be teratogenic. This model can be used to validate other treatments and study other infectious agents affecting brain development.
chunks.chunk_summary: The chick embryo model allows for studying systemic ZIKV infection on human neurons and testing potential therapeutics like niclosamide.
chunks.authors: ["Dana M. Cairns", "Devi Sri Sai Kavya Boorugu", "Michael Levin", "David K. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: hiNSCs were infected with ZIKV strain MR-766 and infection was confirmed by immunostaining, NS1 ELISA, and qRT-PCR. Niclosamide (NIC) treatment before or concurrently with infection reduced ZIKV production, but treatment 3 days post-infection did not. ZIKV-infected hiNSCs secreted cytokines and growth factors like CXCL10, LIF, and VEGF, which were also upregulated at the mRNA level. NIC treatment partially reduced their expression. ZIKV infection altered hiNSC differentiation, increasing VGAT (GABAergic marker) and decreasing VGLUT2 (glutamatergic marker) expression. NIC reduced VGAT upregulation but did not fully restore VGLUT2. Pre- or concurrent NIC treatment prevented ZIKV-induced apoptosis in hiNSCs. These in vitro results informed the timing of drug treatment for in vivo studies.
chunks.topic: In vitro effects of ZIKV and NIC on hiNSCs
chunks.chunk_summary: ZIKV infection alters hiNSC cytokine secretion, differentiation, and viability, while NIC treatment can mitigate these effects in vitro.
chunks.authors: ["Dana M. Cairns", "Devi Sri Sai Kavya Boorugu", "Michael Levin", "David K. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: Intracranial injection of ZIKV-infected hiNSCs into chick embryos caused microcephaly, ocular abnormalities, and reduced forebrain volume.  Systemic ZIKV infection via the CAM in embryos with hiNSCs also caused microcephaly, which NIC partially rescued. ZIKV-infected embryos had shorter body lengths and larger ocular openings. NIC rescued cranial width and height but not body length or eye area. NIC reduced the percentage of ZIKV-infected hiNSCs in vivo and partially restored forebrain area and ventricle size.  CXCL10 expression was upregulated in ZIKV-infected hiNSCs in vivo, but NIC did not rescue this. ZIKV infection increased the percentage of VGAT+ (GABAergic) hiNSCs in vivo, which NIC restored, but it did not affect VGLUT2+ (glutamatergic) hiNSCs.
chunks.topic: In vivo effects of ZIKV and NIC in chick embryos
chunks.chunk_summary: Systemic ZIKV infection in a humanized chick embryo model caused microcephaly and other developmental defects, which were partially rescued by NIC treatment.
chunks.authors: ["Dana M. Cairns", "Devi Sri Sai Kavya Boorugu", "Michael Levin", "David K. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: This study used hiNSCs in a humanized chick embryo model to study ZIKV-induced microcephaly and NIC treatment. In vitro, NIC mitigated ZIKV's effects on hiNSCs. In vivo, systemic ZIKV infection via the CAM caused microcephaly, which NIC partially rescued.  While the model showed microcephaly, ZIKV had minimal effects on the chick embryo without hiNSCs. Chick cells were less infectable and not susceptible to ZIKV-induced cell death compared to hiNSCs.  The humanized model replicated clinical findings of microcephaly, including reduced cranial size, brain abnormalities, and enlarged ventricles.  ZIKV also caused reduced body length, potentially due to hiNSC migration or systemic effects of secreted factors. NIC partially restored forebrain area, ventricle size, and hiNSC differentiation in vivo, but not ocular malformations or CXCL10 upregulation.  NIC alone did not have teratogenic effects. This model can be used to test other therapeutics and study other infectious agents.
chunks.topic: Summary of findings and model implications
chunks.chunk_summary: The humanized chick embryo model provides a platform for studying ZIKV-induced microcephaly and therapeutic interventions, with NIC showing partial efficacy.
chunks.authors: ["Dana M. Cairns", "Devi Sri Sai Kavya Boorugu", "Michael Levin", "David K. Kaplan"]

chunks.text: hiNSCs were generated by reprogramming human foreskin fibroblasts using lentivirus expressing reprogramming factors.  hiNSCs were cultured on MEF feeder layers and differentiated in Neurobasal media. ZIKV strain MR-766 was used for infection. Niclosamide (NIC) was dissolved in methanol:acetone and diluted in culture media. Chick cortical neurons and dermal fibroblasts were isolated from embryos and cultured. Cytokine arrays were performed on hiNSC supernatants. NS1 ELISA kits were used to quantify ZIKV. Immunofluorescence was performed on cells and tissue sections. qRT-PCR was used to analyze gene expression. Embryos were injected intracranially with hiNSCs and infected via the CAM.  NIC was applied to the CAM. Embryos were analyzed for phenotypic changes and histological analysis.
chunks.chunk_summary: This section details the methods used for hiNSC generation, ZIKV infection, NIC treatment, cell culture, cytokine arrays, ELISA, immunofluorescence, qRT-PCR, and in vivo experiments.
